page.title: 15COINAGEHALL STREET (1)
page.content: {Coinagehall Street}is the main street of the town of Helston. From Medieval times until the nineteenth century Helston was the centre of an important tin mining region. The coinage hall was were the quality of the tin from the area was checked and assessed. This building originally served as {the Chapel of Our Lady}and dated back to early medieval times. During the Reformation, in about 1574, it was dissolved by Edward the Second and converted into a coinage hall by the townspeople of Helston. At the end of the eighteenth century the position of the coinage hall in the middle of Helston's main thoroughfare was found to be inconvenient. The two members of parliament for Helston in 1796 wanted to remove and rebuild it in a more convenient part of the town.
